questions.question: What is phishing?
options: An attack involving impersonating trusted institutions to extract data
A type of computer virus that encrypts data
A legal method of password reset
questions.explanation: Phishing is fraud involving impersonating banks, stores, or offices to extract passwords, login data, or money.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of smishing?
options: A fake email from a bank
An SMS message about a package with a suspicious link
A phone call from a fraudster impersonating a bank employee
questions.explanation: Smishing is phishing via SMS, e.g., about an alleged package with a link to a fake website.

questions.question: Which warning signal most commonly occurs in phishing?
options: Language errors and typos
Perfect style and linguistic correctness
Message sent from a close person
questions.explanation: Phishing messages often contain typos, language errors, and unusual phrases.

questions.question: What should you do first if you suspect you clicked on a phishing link and provided your password?
options: Ignore the matter — probably nothing will happen
Immediately change the password and enable 2FA, notify bank/IT
Reply to the same email and ask if it's true
questions.explanation: The most important thing is to immediately change the password (also everywhere it was used), enable 2FA, and report the incident to the bank or IT department.

questions.question: How does spear phishing differ from classic phishing?
options: Spear phishing is mass and non-personalized
Spear phishing uses personalized information about the victim
Spear phishing only concerns social media platforms
questions.explanation: Spear phishing is a highly personalized attack — the fraudster gathers information about the victim to make the message look more credible.

questions.question: Which of the following URLs looks most suspicious?
options: https://bank.com/login
https://bank-example.verify-user.xyz/login
https://secure.bank.com/login
questions.explanation: An address containing additional, unusual domains and words like "verify-user" often indicates a fake website. Pay attention to the actual domain (e.g., bank.com).

questions.question: Which of the following practices best reduces the risk of successful phishing?
options: Enabling two-factor authentication (2FA)
Using the same password everywhere
Clicking links only on phone
questions.explanation: Enabling 2FA adds an additional layer of protection — even if someone learns your password, they won't easily gain access to the account.

questions.question: Which type of attachment is most risky in an email from an unknown sender?
options: An .exe file (executable program)
A .txt file (plain text)
A .jpg image without links
questions.explanation: Executable files (.exe, .scr, etc.) can install malicious software. Attachments from unknown senders should be treated as high risk.

questions.question: What is social engineering?
options: A technique for technical server hacking
Psychological manipulation of people to obtain information or actions
Automatic network scanning for vulnerabilities
questions.explanation: Social engineering is the use of manipulation, trust, and emotions (e.g., fear, rush) to convince people to reveal information or perform actions.

questions.question: How is it best to verify whether a received email from a "bank" is genuine?
options: Reply directly to the email and ask
Hover over the link and click if it looks good
Call the bank's official number or go to the website by typing the address in the browser
questions.explanation: The safest way is to contact through official channels — call the number from the bank's official website or type the address manually in the browser. Do not reply to suspicious emails or click links.
